summary: The documents discuss emigration primarily in the context of American defectors in the USSR and the departure of Lee Harvey Oswald and his wife from the Soviet Union. Two documents focus on William Hamilton Martin and Bernon Ferguson Mitchell, former NSA defectors, with one detailing their desire to leave the USSR and another reporting on Vernon Mitchell's potential emigration to Canada. The third document concerns inconsistencies between CIA and State Department information regarding the OSWALDs' departure from the USSR, which was discussed with a staff member of the Warren Commission. The documents highlight the interest of US agencies in the movement and potential relocation of individuals who had connections to the USSR, either through defection or residence.
significance: In the JFK context, emigration is significant because it relates to the circumstances surrounding Lee Harvey Oswald's time in the Soviet Union and his subsequent return to the United States. Discrepancies in the official accounts of the Oswalds' departure from the USSR raised questions and prompted scrutiny from the Warren Commission, contributing to the ongoing investigation into the assassination.
